poem:
Title: A Confectioner's Solace

Austere the season, hardened like Spartan sons,
But oh, the sweetness within crinckled covers.
On bitter moor, under pallor of unknowing suns,
An antidote emerges, wrapped, beloved.

A gilded beacon, Lina's blend, white with coffee hint,
Carries comfort through the winter's wordless song.
We, infant January, suckle on this pleasure mint,
To endure in chocolate-armed strength, the months long.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Notes on chocolate: comfort is at hand for these cruel months We are almost through January, which is one of the hardest months. I always think of January and February as being the offspring of Spartan parents: no mollycoddling and left on a mountainside to survive or die. I love the geeky details Table put on their wrappers… What better antidote to this than chocolate? I started with Lina Stores Cioccolato Bianco al Caffè, £8.95/100g,". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
